item.title: Enable Cookies
item.content:
"Cookies" are little pieces of data we send when you visit our store. Cookies help us get to know you better and personalize your experience. Plus they help protect you and other shoppers from fraud.

Set your browser to accept cookies so you can buy items, save items, and receive customized recommendations. Here’s how:

  • Google Chrome
  • Internet Explorer
  • Safari
  • Mozilla/Firefox

item.title: Privacy and Cookie Policy
item.content:
This privacy policy sets out how this website (hereafter "the Store") uses and protects any information that you give the Store while using this website. The Store is committed to ensuring that your privacy is protected. Should we ask you to provide certain information by which you can be identified when using this website, then you can be assured that it will only be used in accordance with this privacy statement. The Store may change this policy from time to time by updating this page. You should check this page from time to time to ensure that you are happy with any changes.

 

 

1. What we collect

We may collect the following information:

  • Name
  • Contact information including email address
  • Demographic information such as postcode, preferences, and interests
  • Other information relevant to customer surveys and/or offers
  • For the exhaustive list of cookies, we collect see the List of cookies we collect section.

 

 

2. What we do with the information we gather

We require this information to understand your needs and provide you with a better service, and in particular for the following reasons:

  • Internal record keeping.
  • We may use the information to improve our products and services.
  • We may periodically send promotional emails about new products, special offers, or other information which we think you may find interesting using the email address which you have provided.
  • From time to time, we may also use your information to contact you for market research purposes. We may contact you by email, phone, fax, or mail. We may use the information to customize the website according to your interests.

 

3. Security

We are committed to ensuring that your information is secure. In order to prevent unauthorized access or disclosure, we have put in place suitable physical, electronic, and managerial procedures to safeguard and secure the information we collect online.

 

 

4. How we use cookies

A cookie is a small file that asks permission to be placed on your computer's hard drive. Once you agree, the file is added and the cookie helps analyze web traffic or lets you know when you visit a particular site. Cookies allow web applications to respond to you as an individual. The web application can tailor its operations to your needs, likes, and dislikes by gathering and remembering information about your preferences.

We use traffic log cookies to identify which pages are being used. This helps us analyze data about web page traffic and improve our website in order to tailor it to customer needs. We only use this information for statistical analysis purposes and then the data is removed from the system.

Overall, cookies help us provide you with a better website, by enabling us to monitor which pages you find useful and which you do not. A cookie in no way gives us access to your computer or any information about you, other than the data you choose to share with us. You can choose to accept or decline cookies. Most web browsers automatically accept cookies, but you can usually modify your browser setting to decline cookies if you prefer. This may prevent you from taking full advantage of the website.

 

 

5. Links to other websites

Our website may contain links to other websites of interest. However, once you have used these links to leave our site, you should note that we do not have any control over that other website. Therefore, we cannot be responsible for the protection and privacy of any information which you provide whilst visiting such sites and such sites are not governed by this privacy statement. You should exercise caution and look at the privacy statement applicable to the website in question.

Controlling your personal information
You may choose to restrict the collection or use of your personal information in the following ways:

whenever you are asked to fill in a form on the website, look for the box that you can click to indicate that you do not want the information to be used by anybody for direct marketing purposes
if you have previously agreed to us using your personal information for direct marketing purposes, you may change your mind at any time by letting us know using our Contact Us information
We will not sell, distribute or lease your personal information to third parties unless we have your permission or are required by law to do so. We may use your personal information to send you promotional information about third parties which we think you may find interesting if you tell us that you wish this to happen.

You may request details of personal information which we hold about you under the Data Protection Act 1998. A small fee will be payable. If you would like a copy of the information held on you please email us this request using our Contact Us information.

If you believe that any information we are holding on you is incorrect or incomplete, please write to or email us as soon as possible, at the above address. We will promptly correct any information found to be incorrect.

 

 

6. List of cookies we collect

The table below lists the cookies we collect and what information they store.

COOKIE Name COOKIE Description
Cart The association with your shopping cart.
Category Info Stores the category info on the page, which allows displaying pages more quickly.
 Compare The items that you have in the Compare Products list.
Customer An encrypted version of your customer id with the store.
Customer Auth An indicator if you are currently logged into the store.
Customer Indo An encrypted version of the customer group you belong to.
Customer Segment Ids Stores the Customer Segment ID

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.content:
The Company Private Limited Policy

The Company Private Limited and each of their respective subsidiary, parent, and affiliated companies is deemed to operate this Website (“we” or “us”) recognizes that you care how information about you is used and shared. We have created this Privacy Policy to inform you what information we collect on the Website, how we use your information, and the choices you have about the way your information is collected and used. Please read this.

Privacy Policy carefully.  Your use of the Website indicates that you have read and accepted our privacy practices, as outlined in this Privacy Policy.

 Please be advised that the practices described in this Privacy Policy apply to information gathered by us or our subsidiaries, affiliates, or agents:

  • Through this Website
  • Where applicable, through our Customer Service Department in connection with this Website
  • Through information provided to us in our free-standing retail stores, and
  • Through information provided to us in conjunction with marketing promotions and sweepstakes.

We are not responsible for the content or privacy practices on any websites

We reserve the right, in our sole discretion, to modify, update, add to, discontinue, remove or otherwise change any portion of this Privacy Policy, in whole or in part, at any time. When we amend this Privacy Policy, we will revise the “last updated” date located at the top of this Privacy Policy.

If you provide information to us or access or use the Website in any way after this Privacy Policy has been changed, you will be deemed to have unconditionally consented and agreed to such changes. The most current version of this Privacy Policy will be available on the Website and will supersede all previous versions of this Privacy Policy.

If you have any questions regarding this Privacy Policy, you should contact our Customer Service Department by email at marketing@company.com

item.title: Product Warrenty
item.content:
Product Warranty

Lifetime Manufacturer Warranty

We stand behind our products and warrant that all items will be free from manufacturing defects for the life of the products. If you believe your item has a manufacturing defect, you may return it to us for inspection. If we determine your merchandise is damaged due to a manufacturing defect, we will repair the merchandise or, if we deem appropriate, replace the item. If the item is no longer available, Blue Nile may, in its discretion, replace with like-kind or allow a refund equal to the selling price of the original item or component.

If we determine that the damage is not caused by a manufacturing defect, then we will notify you and let you know if repair services are available at cost or otherwise.

Please note that slight irregularities and variations in craftsmanship or natural characteristics, or internal inclusions, visible or otherwise, in coloured gemstones are unique and individual to each item. These characteristics are considered as part of the character of the item, and should not be considered a defect.

Complimentary Cleaning And Inspection Services On Diamond Rings

We recommend having your diamond ring cleaned and inspected every six months or if it undergoes any potential trauma. Inspections may help prevent the loss of a stone and extend the life of your jewellery. This cleaning and inspection service is free of charge to Blue Nile customers on their Blue Nile diamond rings. The customer only pays for shipping, and Blue Nile pays for return shipping. Repairs to your ring mounting can also be done at this time at cost.

Conditions And Exclusions

The foregoing Manufacturer Warranty and Complimentary Services are available only to the person who purchased the covered product from Blue Nile.

Maintenance, repair, sizing or other service performed by someone other than Blue Nile will void your Manufacturer Warranty.

Fine jewellery is not impervious to normal wear, activities or trauma. This is particularly true for rings since hands are regularly subjected to considerable abuse. We do not provide warranties for damage due to normal wear, product loss, loss of stones or theft. Damage or loss that results from failure to obtain repairs necessary to maintain the integrity of the product are also not covered.

Some examples of common jewellery issues that would not be considered manufacturing defects include:

  1. Discoloration due to exposure to chemicals, make-up, swimming pools, hot tubs or bathing.
  2. Prongs and precious metals, in general, wear over time and may require “building up” or restoration work as normal wear.
  3. Bent, caught or worn out prongs(s) allowing a stone to fall out or be lost due to normal wear or other damage.
  4. Lost stone or a stone has fallen out due to chipping or breaking caused by normal wear or other damage

item.content: <style> @media screen and (min-width: 601px) { .h1 { font-family: Noto Serif; text-align: center; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; font-size: 40px; line-height: 48px; color: #000000; } .p{ margin-left: 72px; margin-right: 72px; margin-top: 60px; font-size: 12px; font-family: Montserrat; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 14px; line-height: 24px; /* or 171% */ display: flex; align-items: center; text-align: center; letter-spacing: 0.005em; } } @media screen and (max-width: 600px) { .h1 { font-size: 20px; text-align: center; font-family: Noto Serif; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; font-size: 20px; line-height: 24px; /* identical to box height, or 120% */ display: flex; align-items: center; text-align: center; color: #000000; } .p{ margin-left: 16px; margin-right: 16px; margin-top: 24px; font-size: 12px; font-family: Montserrat; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 14px; line-height: 24px; /* or 171% */ display: flex; align-items: center; text-align: center; letter-spacing: 0.005em; } } </style> </head> <body> <div class="h1">Conflict-free Diamonds (Our Guarantee)</div> <div class="p"> <p>The Diamond ICQ team understands the importance of where diamonds come from. We share the same concern with our customers. Our diamonds are conflict-free under the Patriot Act, the Kimberley Process, and UN resolutions. Moreover, our internal guidelines go beyond government requirements: Our contract with our suppliers ensures that the diamonds we sell are conflict-free and in compliance with all applicable laws. Polished diamonds are purchased only from sources in the world of the professional diamond trade. </p> </div> </body>

item.content:
Gift Card

 

 

Send a free personalized gift card with your jewellery order. Select “Free Gift Card” on the order review page and craft your personal message. We’ll print your message on a card and include it with your jewellery.

item.title: Terms & Conditions
item.content:
These Terms and Conditions May Change

We reserve the right to update or modify these terms and conditions at any time without prior notice.  Your use of shop.company.com and shop.beetlebug.com.sg following any such change constitutes your agreement to follow and be bound by the terms and conditions as changed. For this reason, we encourage you to review these terms and conditions whenever you use this website.

Limitations of Liability

The Company Pte Ltd shall not assume any responsibility, and shall not be liable for, any damages to, or viruses that may infect, your computer, telecommunication equipment, or other property caused by or arising from your access to, use of, or browsing this website or your downloading of any materials, from this website. IN NO EVENT WILL THE COMPANY PRIVATE LIMITED NOR THEIR RESPECTIVE OFFICERS, DIRECTORS, EMPLOYEES, SHAREHOLDERS, AFFILIATES, AGENTS, SUCCESSORS, ASSIGNS, RETAIL PARTNERS NOR ANY PARTY INVOLVED IN THE CREATION, PRODUCTION OR TRANSMISSION OF THIS WEB SITE BE LIABLE TO ANY PARTY FOR ANY INDIRECT, SPECIAL, PUNITIVE, INCIDENTAL OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES (INCLUDING, WITHOUT LIMITATION, THOSE RESULTING FROM LOST PROFITS, LOST DATA OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) ARISING OUT OF THE USE, INABILITY TO USE, OR THE RESULTS OF USE OF THIS WEB SITE, ANY WEB SITES LINKED TO THIS WEB SITE, OR THE MATERIALS, INFORMATION OR SERVICES CONTAINED AT ANY OR ALL SUCH SITES, WHETHER BASED ON WARRANTY, CONTRACT, TORT OR ANY OTHER LEGAL THEORY AND WHETHER OR NOT ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGES. THE FOREGOING LIMITATIONS OF LIABILITY DO NOT APPLY TO THE EXTENT PROHIBITED BY LAW. PLEASE REFER TO YOUR LOCAL LAWS FOR ANY SUCH PROHIBITIONS.

IN THE EVENT OF ANY PROBLEM WITH THIS WEBSITE OR ANY CONTENT, YOU AGREE THAT YOUR SOLE REMEDY IS TO CEASE USING THIS WEBSITE. IN THE EVENT OF ANY PROBLEM WITH THE PRODUCTS OR SERVICES THAT YOU HAVE PURCHASED ON OR THROUGH THIS WEB SITE, YOU AGREE THAT YOUR REMEDY, IF ANY, IS FROM THE MANUFACTURER OF SUCH PRODUCTS OR SUPPLIER OF SUCH SERVICES, IN ACCORDANCE WITH SUCH MANUFACTURER’S OR SUPPLIER’S WARRANTY, OR TO SEEK A RETURN AND REFUND FOR SUCH PRODUCT OR SERVICES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE RETURNS AND REFUNDS POLICIES POSTED ON THIS WEB SITE. This site may include inaccuracies, mistakes or typographical errors. CharlesKeith.com does not warrant that the content will be uninterrupted or error free.

Copyright and Trademark

Unless otherwise indicated, material on this website, including but not limited to texts, images, illustrations, software, audio clips, video clips, animation files, is subject to the copyright and trademark rights of The Company Private Limited. Consequently, the material on this website may not be copied, reproduced, modified, posted, transmitted, distributed, in whole or in part in any form whatsoever, without the prior written consent of The Company Private Limited. All rights reserved.

Products, Content and Specifications

All features, content, specifications, products and prices of products and services described or depicted on this website are subject to change at any time without notice.  Certain weights, measures and similar descriptions are approximate and are provided for convenience purposes only.  We make all reasonable efforts to accurately display the attributes of our products, including the applicable colors; however, the actual color you see will depend on your computer system and we cannot guarantee that your computer will accurately display such colors.  The inclusion of any products or services in this website at a particular time does not imply or warrant that these products or services will be available at any time.  It is your responsibility to ascertain and obey all applicable local, state and international laws in regard to the possession, use and sale of any item purchased from this website. By placing an order, you represent that the products ordered will be used only in a lawful manner.

Shipping Limitations

When an order is placed, it will be shipped to an address designated by the purchaser as long as that shipping address is compliant with the shipping restrictions contained on this website.  All purchases from this website are made pursuant to a shipment contract.  As a result, risk of loss and title for items purchased from this website pass to you upon delivery of the items to the carrier.  You are responsible for filing any claims with carriers for damaged and/or lost shipments.

Duties and Taxes

You are responsible for duties and taxes outside Singapore. All items entering a foreign country are subject to customs inspection and assessment of the duties and taxes in accordance with that country’s national laws.

Your Account

You are responsible for maintaining the confidentiality of your account and password information, and you agree to accept responsibility for all activities that occur under your account and password.  This website and The Company Pte Ltd reserves the right to refuse service, terminate accounts remove or edit content or cancel orders.

By placing an order, you warrant that you are over 18 years of age, and that you are providing shop.company.com or shop.beetlebug.com.sg with accurate, truthful information and that you have the authority to place the order.

Exchange and Refund Policy (Singapore Outlets Only)

New, unused full-price merchandise purchased at store retail store may be exchange at any boutique with an original receipt within 7 days of purchase. After 7 days, the merchandise may not be exchanged.

We offer a no-refund policy on all merchandises, however, for merchandise qualifying for an exchange, item may be exchange for store credits which may be used at our Singapore outlets only.

Merchandise on sale may not be exchanged or returned. All merchandise must be returned in sellable condition, otherwise, an exchange would not be allowed.

We reserve the right to reject any form of exchange without the original receipt.

Exchange and Refund Policy (Online Shop)

Electronice Communications

When you visit this website and/or send email to us, you consent to receive electronic communications from us. You agree that all agreements, notices, disclosures and other communications that we sent you electronically satisfy any legal requirement that such communications be in writing

Exclusions of Warranties

The Company Private Limited makes no representative or warranty regarding the good working order or condition of this website, its suitability for use, or that its use will be uninterrupted or error-free. All information or material provided in this website to you â€œas isâ€ and without warranties of any kind, expressed or implied, including without limitation, warranties or conditions of merchantability, fitness, quality, durability or suitability for any particular purpose, or non-infringement.

item.title: About Us - Design Own Jewellery
item.content:
{{widget type="Magento\Cms\Block\Widget\Block" template="widget/static_block/default.phtml" block_id="39" type_name="CMS Static Block"}}

Design Own Jewellery 

Diamond ICQ is your introduction to everything to love about diamond jewellery. We aim to strike the perfect balance between accessible and personalised jewellery that reflects who you are. This allows you to build your jewellery from scratch with designs inspired by icons. We have the know-how with the perfect canvas for you to bring your story to life. We go above and beyond to provide you with personalised jewellery at your convenience.

Design your own engagement ring and any other jewellery that is customised uniquely to you and made to order in-house. Our rings aren’t just jewellery - they tell stories. After all, it is you who will be wearing your signature style. It is your unique story. Your individuality matters. With Diamond ICQ, the customization of your jewellery to your tastes matters. It’s your style and freedom for you to choose how you want to look.

item.title: About Us - Marketplace
item.content:
{{widget type="Magento\Cms\Block\Widget\Block" template="widget/static_block/default.phtml" block_id="39" type_name="CMS Static Block"}}

Marketplace

At Diamond ICQ marketplace we bring sellers directly to connect with all buyers to make your buying experience more personable. As you bypass the middleman, often a retailer, you can obtain the very best near wholesale prices from all the marketplace sellers. Also with the marketplace, you are able to buy directly from other people, just like yourself. That means you will be able to receive fantastic unable prices for diamonds and jewelry as you get to bypass all middlemen, and speak with the owners directly. Only at Diamond ICQ has such a shopping platform existed on such a wide scale. We are proud to bring this vast shopping experience to you where you can source the finest in jewellery at affordable prices.

  • Now you can even have the option of getting all your marketplace purchases verified by professional diamond laboratories like IGI and be given an IGI certificate for all your jewelry purchases.
  • This is fantastic for pre-owned jewelry as you can get the bonus reassurance verified by an unbiased third-party laboratory that what you are buying and paying for is really what you get as listed in the description.
  • That means you can buy with ease with professional gemologists and a body of professional laboratories verifying your every purchase.
  • It even comes with a handy IGI certificate that you can keep with your diamonds and jewelry so for insurance or resale purposes you have certificates to outline your jewelry specifications.
  • IGI is one of the world’s renowned and trusted gemology laboratories and to have them grade your jewelry ensures that your purchase is top-notch matching your purchase description.
  • With the option to have third party laboratory appraisals by one of the most respected laboratories worldwide, you would have a company team of gemologiest to guarantee the authenticity of your purchases. That means you can shop with ease on all pre owned diamond jewelry.
  • Diamond ICQ marketplace has the latest leading brands across all jewellery categories, including rings, earrings, bracelets, bangles, necklaces, and any other jewellery pieces that you can imagine.
  • Our team of expert jewellers source and search around the world for the very best quality jewellery masterpieces from the greatest brands.
  • We are proud to showcase these masterpieces to you from the comfort of your phone or computer, where you can view our masterpieces in peace and comfort.

Great jewellery pieces from a wide variety of renowned suppliers globally.

item.title: About Us - Our Concierge Service
item.content:
{{widget type="Magento\Cms\Block\Widget\Block" template="widget/static_block/default.phtml" block_id="39" type_name="CMS Static Block"}}

Our Concierge Service

At Diamond ICQ we are also a full-service jewelry concierge to help you find your dream jewelry stress-free. We also have an extension of second-hand diamonds and offer cash for second-hand diamonds. Proudly endorsed by the Hong Kong Tourism Board (HKTB) with the Quality Tourism Services (QTS) and "No Fakes Pledge", rest assured with Diamond ICQ as we have been authenticated by the Hong Kong Tourism Board.

Design your own jewellery with amazing service of Diamond ICQ.

Hong Kong

Our showroom is in Tsim Sha Tsui, Hong Kong. We specialise in GIA certified top quality natural diamonds. Diamond ICQ is one of the largest diamond stores in Hong Kong with the most comprehensive selection of diamonds. We have a GIA certified diamond grader in-house to ensure top-quality diamonds.

Our certified grader is available to provide professional diamond advice to customers, answer any enquiries, and conduct all quality control checks so you can be guaranteed your diamonds are authentically top quality.

Our customer service team includes senior diamond and jewellery experts to provide you with around the clock service with even a professional jeweller to provide you with individual one to one consultations. Don’t take our word for it; see our extensive positive feedback and reviews from satisfied customers who keep coming back to Diamond ICQ for all their diamond purchases.

item.title: Education
item.content:
Diamond

Diamond is one of the hardest natural minerals and it is also one of the rarest substances on earth. A diamond is a simple crystal and a natural mineral. Diamonds are composed of a single carbon element, naturally formed in high-pressure, high-temperature environments within the deep earth, 120 to 200 kilometres below the surface. As each and every diamond has experienced an extraordinary journey. The Greek word "Adamas" means "unconquerable" and "Immortality" which is the origin of the word "diamond".

1

Buying A Diamond

Diamond ICQ guarantees the main diamond that we select will have no big black spots in the centre of the diamond, the diamond is eye-clean to the naked eye, there will be no milk haze and no brown tints in the diamonds.

Read More

2

4 C’s of Diamond

The diamond shape is the geometric outline and physical form of a diamond. Every diamond shape has its own characteristics and cuts specifications. The shape of a diamond has a huge influence on the appearance of a diamond.

Read More

3

Factors of Diamond Buying A Diamond

The most important components of a diamond are its diameter, table, and depth. This is because the ratio of the table to the diameter, and the depth to diameter, determines a diamond's cut grade.

Read More

Know more about the best ring setting.

Prongs Setting

Channel Setting

Halo Setting

Tiffany Setting

Bezel Setting

Three Stone Setting

Explore All Settings

Natural Gemstones

Sapphire

Sapphires are cherished for their colour. They are most famously known for their vivid blue colour. Fancy sapphires can come in a variety of hues and tones and can also appear in a number of other colours such as pink, yellow, orange, green, violet, black and white.

Rubies

Rubies are the favourite gemstone for those in power and in love due to their intense red colour which also symbolises love and power. The ruby has inspired more emotion than any other stone with its vivid red colour connotations.

Pearls

Pearls are known to be the gems of the sea and are the only gemstones known to mankind that come from a living creature. Since ancient civilisations, pearls have been cherished by society. Pearls come in all shapes and sizes, with the large perfect round ones being the most in-demand.

Read More

Read More

Read More

Metals

Platinum

Platinum is essentially a white metal that looks exactly like white gold except that it is harder and more durable. Platinum is made in nearly its pure form for all jewellery. There is often 95-98% pure platinum used in all platinum jewellery.

Rose Gold

Rose gold is another trendy metal to set jewellery in. It is made of pure gold blended with copper and silver metals to give it that blush tone and make the gold stronger and more robust. If more copper is used then rose gold will look redder. Often for 18 karts rose gold it is a mix of 75% gold and 25% copper.

Read More

Yellow Gold

Yellow is an affordable option to set jewellery in and looks fantastic on numerous skin tones too. Yellow gold is a more traditional precious metal and dates back to when our civilisation started and gold was considered a very precious commodity. Historically yellow gold was the most popular precious metal to be used for wedding and engagement rings.

Read More

White Gold

There are three types of gold to choose from to set your diamond jewellery: white gold, rose gold and yellow gold. They are all very similar, they are just different in their colour and configuration.

Read More

Why choose a stone that looks good with your engagement ring.

Diamond ICQ guarantees the main diamond that we select will have no big black spots in the center of the diamond, the diamond is eye clean to the naked eye, there will be no milk haze and no brown tints in the diamonds.

As Diamond ICQ has the optimal cut quality, all our diamonds have a wonderful brilliance in sparkle. 

There are 4 grades in diamond quality that we offer which guarantees that your

 

diamond will be a beautiful white color with high purity. We recommend the following combinations when selecting your diamond based on your budget: 
Deluxe Quality
E Color, VS2 Clarity, Ex Cut

Premium Quality
F Color,VS2 Clarity, EX Cut

High Quality
G Color, SI1 Clarity, VG Cut

Great Value
H Color, SI2 Clarity, VG Cut


Buying Engagement Ring Guidelines
Many girls, your girlfriend included, long for their big day. A proposal of marriage is seen as a prologue to their dream wedding with the engagement ring an important symbol of a "Happy Wife. Happy Life." 

The most romantic proposal moment in a woman's life is their engagement which must be accompanied with a diamond ring! 

The bride will always wear their engagement ring during the engagement, proclaiming their love and responding to her man’s promise. Her engagement ring, also known as "promotion ring", is the most eye-catching jeweler ring in a wedding. Generally speaking, engagement rings are mainly rings set with a main diamond and worn on the fourth finger of the left hand.

It is said that the tradition of engagement rings came from ancient Rome to prove that "My heart will always belong to you." 

Franky and his business partners are suppliers to many famous brands across the world. Establishing his wholesale business in Hong Kong 15 years ago, Diamond ICQ is proud to stock one of the largest diamond inventories in the city.
Franky's vast contacts and experience in the diamond industry will undoubtedly help you in selecting the best diamonds possible for your jeweler. 

How to select my diamond ring?
Engagement rings typically feature around a center stone, which generally is a diamond. Diamonds are often the feature stone and are often used as they have the meaning of "purity" and "eternity" love, so they are well regarded as the first choice for all engagement rings.

Few basic tips
Diamond + Setting = Diamond Ring
Choose the main stone of the ring according to your personal budget and order a diamond ring that is worthy of your permanent collection.
Choose a forever diamond that is worthy of your collection and choose a ring according to your personal budget and circumstances.


It is said that wearing jeweler is like wearing clothing. There is different tailored clothing to suit each body shape while also accentuating the best features according to our body shape. This also applies when wearing a ring, each person's hand shape, finger size and palm is slightly different. Some people have long fingers while others have slightly bigger knuckles. Whatever the case maybe, when a man is choosing an engagement ring, we can use the lucky lady’s hand shape as a reference point to see what ring and diamond shape would suit her best.

For shorter fingers: 
Short fingers tend to be more suitable for pear-shaped, oval-shaped, straight, or marquise-shaped diamond ring settings as it can make your hands look longer and slender than they really are. It is recommended for shorter fingers to avoid choosing a square diamond, heart shaped, or a diamond ring with wide settings and a large face in the setting as these kinds of settings makes the fingers appear shorter. With bigger and thicker fingers a more simple diamond shape is more suited in making a finger appear more slender. 

For slender fingers: 
If the ring wear has slender fingers basically any style of ring and setting will match them perfectly. 

Skin tones for ring design: 
For darker skin tones it is best avoid the white gold setting. Try to choose gold settings or even colored gemstones to brighten the skin color of your hand. 
With lighter skin tones practically anything suits you so feel free to explore different ranges in metals and stones. 

Wearing the Engagement ring on middle finger vs ring finger?
In Asian cultures, engagement rings are worn on the left middle finger, and then once married the diamond engagement ring and wedding is moved onto the ring finger. 
In western cultures, the engagement ring is worn on the ring finger of the left hand. This stems from an ancient Roman tradition where they believe that the blood vessels of the left ring finger passed through the heart and were the veins of love, so they were considered the best fingers to wear engagement rings.

4C's of Diamond

Article By The Diamond ICQ
September 24, 2017

Shear with Friends

Why choose a stone that looks good with your engagement ring.

Diamond cut
Diamonds are infamous for their ability sparkle intensely as they are able to transmit light in every direction. Diamond’s cut means how well-proportioned and well cut its dimensions are, and how well these surfaces, also known as facets, are positioned to create sparkle and brilliance. Cut helps determine the diamond’s beauty and price. Masterful craftsmanship and workmanship is absolutely necessary to cut a diamond stone perfectly so that its symmetry, proportions and polish brings the splendid return of light that is only possible in a real diamond.

Accomplishing the very best cut in a diamond displays the diamond’s final beauty and prized value. Out of the 4Cs in diamonds, cut is the most important. It is also the most intricate and hardest to analyze. For example, to define the cut grade of the most popular and in demand diamond shape, the round brilliant diamond, GIA needs to calculate every single proportion in the round diamond’s facets which affect the diamond’s face-up appearance. The facet proportions of a diamond helps diamond laboratory graders to determine the best cut for the diamond. 


Choosing cuts
When choosing GIA cut grades, choose from the below cuts:
Good cut
Good cut for a diamond with all the fire and sparkle 
Very good cut
Great quality cut which reflects light even better making the diamond more sparkly at a budget friendly price
Excellent cut
Outstanding cut above the rest that creates the most brilliance. A very rare cut that makes the fire inside the diamond sparkle even more. 

Diamond cut
A diamond laboratory grader, such as the GIA diamond laboratory graders, studies how successfully a diamond interacts and interfaces with light to produce the fire and sparkle based on factors such as:
Fire: this is how light is scattered across into the colors of the rainbow by the diamond

Brightness and brilliance: this is how well the diamond reflects light and how light is reflected within the diamond as well as outside of the diamond 
Facets of the diamond: this is the ratio of the diamond’s diameter in comparison to its depth. This also affects the light performance of a diamond. 
Scintillation: This refers to the volume of sparkle that a diamond creates. This also includes the pattern of brightened lighter and darker areas produced by the light reflected within the diamond. It measures the contrast between dark and light areas in the diamond. It’s the wow factor and sparkle in a diamond

Diamond cut is one of the most important factors of a diamond as cut determines the sparkle factor of a diamond. 

Well cut diamonds has the very best in brilliance, fire, and scintillation
Even a diamond with the highest color and clarity grade can appear dull if the cut is not done properly and is too shallow or deep.
GIA’s diamond cut grade also takes into account the design and craftsmanship of the diamond, including its weight relative to its diameter, its girdle thickness (which affects its durability), the symmetry of its facet arrangement, and the quality of polish on those facets.

The GIA Diamond Cut Scale for standard round brilliant diamonds in the D-to-Z diamond color range contains 5 grades ranging from Excellent to Poor and is the definitive scale for classifying diamond cuts.

Diamond cut and shape are very different 
Diamond cut, and diamond shape mean different things and often people can get them mixed up and confused. Sometimes when we hear of a diamond cut, we could think that this is referring to a diamond’s cut shape, such as round, heart, oval, marquise, pear cut. However, a diamond shape refers to the outline of a diamond. The round brilliant shaped diamond is the most popular shape worldwide. Other shapes that are non-rounded fancy shaped could possibly save you up to 25% which is a possibility to consider if you are on a budget.  

On the other hand, a diamond cut actually means is how the diamond’s many facets interact with light and allows light to pass through it. Diamond cut is the light performance of a diamond. This is based on the overall surface condition of a diamond’s facets. Multiple factors can affect this such as the diamond’s proportions, symmetry, and polish.

Diamond Cut: Most expensive cut of a diamond
The cut of a diamond is the biggest factor in the price tag for a diamond. Although it seem that way as everyone tends to focus on the diamond’s carat weight instead. Excellent cuts are the most expensive diamond cuts as they optimize light performance and create the most brilliant sparkles. This is because cut has one of the greatest impacts on a diamond’s beauty and sparkle.

Anatomy of a diamond
The most important components of a diamond are its diameter, table, and depth. This is because the ratio of the table to the diameter, and the depth to diameter, determines a diamond's cut grade.
 
Table: The largest facet of a diamond

Crown: The top portion of a diamond extending from the girdle to the table

Girdle: The intersection of the crown and pavilion which defines the circumference of a diamond

Diameter: The measurement from one girdle edge of a diamond straight across to the opposing side

Pavilion: The bottom portion of a diamond, extending from the girdle to the culet

Culet: The facet at the tip of a gemstone. The preferred culet is not visible with the unaided eye and needs a magnification glass to be seen

Depth: The height of a gemstone measured from the culet to the table

These various parts of a diamond and how well they are cut are part of a diamond's cut grade.

How does the pavilion of a diamond affect its cut? 
The distance from the bottom of the girdle to the culet is the called the diamond’s pavilion depth. If the diamond’s pavilion depth is too shallow or too deep it would let too much light to escape from the side of the diamond or leak out from the bottom, decreasing the sparkle factor for the diamond. An excellent to well-cut diamond will redirect the most light through its crown.


Diamond color
It is very rare to find a diamond with no color at all. In fact, almost all natural diamonds have a tint of other colors within them, including grey, white, yellow, brown and red. 
A diamond’s color is classified by 23 English alphabets. The highest color is D which represents the whitest / colorless diamond grade and the lowest grade is Z color. 
The most popular color is the whitest / colorless diamond. These colors are in the grades G and above. As we descend lower into the color grades, the yellow within a diamond becomes more obvious.

The Chinese generally do not use English letters to represent color, they call D color full color, E Color 99 color, F color 98 color, etc. While shopping for a diamond, you could consider near-colorless diamonds instead of absolutely colorless as you can hardly see any difference with your eyes between the two if it is not compared with other diamonds. 

Diamond color grades are very subtle, and often cannot detected with the naked eye. You would need a professional appraiser with a master set of colorimetric stones before a diamond color could be properly analyzed. 
Diamond color is divided into five levels:
D, E, F colors are colorless diamonds. 
G, H, I, J colors are almost near colorless diamonds.
K, L, M colors are slightly yellow tinted diamonds
N, O, P, Q, R colors are very pale yellow diamonds.
S to Z colors are light yellow diamond grades. 
Diamonds with a color above Z will be classified as fancy colored diamonds.


Tips for diamond color
Diamond valuation for white diamonds is determined by the absence of color. The more absent of color a diamond is the more valuable and expansive it is. However this does not apply to fancy vivid colors where the opposite is true, namely the more of one color it the fancy colored diamond is, the more expansive it is

The color of a ring’s setting, such as platinum and yellow gold, can affect the appearance of the diamond’s color.

Near-colorless diamonds have no obvious color to the naked eye and are a great value for money. These include the G-H color diamonds and the I-J color diamonds

Faint color diamonds are the most budget-friendly diamonds. These are the K Color Diamonds and go perfectly with yellow gold settings. 

Prices are cheaper as you increase in alphabetical order. For example, a diamond with a I color grade is cheaper than a diamond with a D color grade.


Color is more visible in large diamonds than small diamonds
Diamond valuation for white diamonds is determined by the absence of color. The more absent of color a diamond is the more valuable and expansive it is. However this does not apply to fancy vivid colors where the opposite is true, namely the more of one color it the fancy colored diamond is, the more expansive it is

The color of a ring’s setting, such as platinum and yellow gold, can affect the appearance of the diamond’s color.

Near-colorless diamonds have no obvious color to the naked eye and are a great value for money. These include the G-H color diamonds and the I-J color diamonds

Faint color diamonds are the most budget-friendly diamonds. These are the K Color Diamonds and go perfectly with yellow gold settings. 

Prices are cheaper as you increase in alphabetical order. For example, a diamond with a I color grade is cheaper than a diamond with a D color grade.

Diamond colors can be chosen based on diamond shape and setting
Some fancy-shaped diamonds can hide color better than others and costs up to 25% less than a round-cut diamond. Also consider the setting of color and choose one that best compliments the color grade of your diamond. For example, yellow gold casts a warm yellow glow and looks best with diamonds with faint color, such as a k color diamond. Platinum or white gold will make a near-colorless diamond look icier.
Diamond color: 


Fancy colored diamonds


Fancy colored diamonds are a lot more expensive than the white colorless diamonds. This is because they are quite rare with only 1 in every 10,000 diamonds are a fancy color diamond. The more intense the fancy color is, the more rare, valuable, and expansive the diamond. Fancy-colored diamonds are graded on a separate color scale and are even more valuable than white diamonds.


A history of diamond color through different cultures


In the eastern culture, such as the Chinese, they generally do not use English letters to represent color but use numeric grades. A D color will be called full color, E color will be called 99 color, F color is called 98 color, and the metric continues with each alphabet letter corresponding to a metric number. 
When choosing a diamond, if you are on a budget, it may be wise to choose a near-colorless diamond instead of absolutely colorless diamonds. This is because with the naked eye you cannot see any difference in color between colorless and near colorless diamonds, especially as you would not compare your jeweler with other diamonds directly. 

 

Clarity 
When looking at clarity of a diamond, we need to understand the natural formation of a diamond. All diamonds are unique, but not perfect. Diamonds are produced underground through pressure and heat. Such a natural process of formation would of course eventuate in natural inclusions and flaws within a diamond. During the formation of a natural diamond, it will bring various cracks, defects and inclusions into a diamond. These features or inclusions are unique marks, some would even call these inclusions birthmarks of a diamond. That is why a diamond certificate is paramount in determining the quality of a diamond. 

The GIA Diamond Clarity Scale has 6 categories, which are divided into a total of 11 specific grades: 
Flawless (FL): No inclusions and no blemishes visible under 10x magnification
Internally Flawless (IF): No inclusions visible under 10x magnification
Very, Very Slightly Included (VVS1 and VVS2): Inclusions so slight they are difficult for a skilled grader to see under 10x magnification
Very Slightly Included (VS1 and VS2): Inclusions are found and seen with effort under 10x magnification and is characterized as minor
Slightly Included (SI1 and SI2): Inclusions are noticeable under 10x magnification
Included (I1, I2, and I3): Inclusions are obvious under 10x magnification which may affect transparency and brilliance. The inclusions in these grades can sometimes be observed with the naked eye without any microscope or magnification needed. 


Clarity 
Diamond Clarity Plots
Clarity plots are diagrams which show the location of imperfections—mapping the blemishes of a diamond and the inclusions within the diamond’s interior. These inclusions are identified by a certified diamond grader using 10x magnifications.


Clarity: Many Different Types Of Diamond Inclusions And Blemishes 
Types Of Diamond Inclusions:
Clouds
Feathers
Crystals or minerals
Knots
Cavities
Cleavage
Internal graining


Types Of Blemish Examples:
Polish lines
Scratches
Nicks
Pits
Chips
Breaks
Dark or light spots

Types Of Diamond Inclusions
Internal and external characteristics of a diamond (also known as inclusions):
Bruise: this is a miniscule concussion mark on the surface of the diamond that could create small root-like lines inside the stone. A tiny bruise can make the difference between the top IF clarity grade and a VVS1 clarity grade.
Cavity: this is a tiny opening on the surface of the diamond which was created when part of a feather was broken away. In higher clarity grades, this is nearly impossible to see with the naked eye.

Chip: A small opening in the diamond stemming from the cutting process or damage to the stone’s surface. More serious larger chips could result in considerable carat weight loss. In higher clarity grades, the chip may be impossible to see with the naked eye.

Cloud: A cluster of tiny pinpoints inside a diamond which are too small to see them individually. With higher clarity diamonds, clouds more difficult to detect under magnification. On grading reports of lower clarity diamonds, there may be a note stating that “clarity is based on clouds not shown”. These are called “micro-clouds” which on a rare occasion can be somewhat eye-visible.
Crystal: A tiny, miniscule bit of mineral or other matter within a diamond. They come in all shapes, sizes and color and could even extend to the diamond’s surface.

Extra Facet: these are additional facets which are not required by the diamond’s cutting style and are outside of the diamond’s overall facet pattern or symmetry. These extra facets are often found near the girdle.

Feather: any fracture in a diamond that goes to the diamond’s surface. In higher clarity diamonds, feathers may be so shallow that its difficult to find them even under magnification.

Indented Natural: An indented edge or a part of the original rough diamond that has been left unpolished. It dips below the surface of the finished, polished diamond.
Knot: A transparent crystal that goes to the surface of the diamond 
Laser Drill Hole: A tiny hole on the surface of a diamond that leads to a tunnel which has been drilled into a diamond. These types of holes are often drilled in to remove an internal inclusion and are a form of diamond enhancement. Once a diamond has been enhanced, they then become unnatural clarity enhanced diamonds. 
Natural: A section of the original rough diamond’s surface left unpolished on the finished diamond. Typically found near the girdle and often undetectable to the naked eye in the face-up position. 
Needle: A thin, fine, long inclusion that is within the interior of a diamond. It looks like a tiny needle under magnification. Needles are general subtle and less obvious than crystals or feathers.

Pinpoint: tiny minute crystals in the interior of a diamond. They look like tiny specks under magnification. The presence of a single pinpoint can make the difference between an Internally Flawless and VVS1 clarity grade.

Twinning Wisp: during the diamond’s growth a series of tiny pinpoints, clouds or crystals can be formed within the diamond. These wisps can produce an irregularity in the diamond’s crystal structure. They often appear as a ripple or wispy line in the diamond.


Clarity Tips
You will hear the term “eye clean” used a lot in regards to clarity. Eye clean simply means that the diamond’s inclusions are too small to see without any aid such as a magnification glass.
To maximize your spending budget, a clarity grade of Slightly Included (SI) and Very Slightly Included (VS) grades are great as the inclusions within these diamonds will not be easily noticeable without any magnification.
Clarity is deemed slightly less important than a diamond’s cut or color as cut or color is more noticeable than clarity to the naked eye
A diamond’s shape and size can affect clarity. If you are planning on buying any diamond over one carat or even fancy-shaped diamonds, like an emerald or Ascher cut, you may need to get a  higher clarity grade as flaws are more visible in bigger diamonds and fancy shaped diamonds
Diamond clarity can affect a diamond’s beauty although you don’t need to get the highest high clarity grade to avoid seeing imperfections with the naked eye. 

Diamond Clarity Factors to consider
Size: The larger or more noticeable an inclusion is in a diamond, then likely the lower the clarity grade is for that diamond.

Number of inclusions: The more inclusions and blemishes easily seen, the lower the clarity grade. Similarly, the fewer inclusions easily seen means the higher the clarity grade as more expansive the diamond.

Position of inclusions: notice the position of the inclusions. If the blemish is right under the table and closer to the pavilion (see anatomy of diamonds to understand where a table and pavilion is located on a diamond), then this turns the inclusion onto a reflector which would impact its clarity grade. 

Nature and type of inclusion: the nature and type of diamond inclusion could impact the durability of the diamond.

 

Diamond Clarity: Getting a great value diamond with great clarity, a VS or a SI diamond:
Many inclusions are too small to be seen by the naked eye and require a loupe and a trained diamond grader to even see the inclusion. To the everyday naked eye, an eye that is not using a loupe or microscope, a graded VS1 and an SI2 diamond could very well look the same. However, a VS1 and an SI2 diamonds are actually quite different in quality and price point. For the best value, pick a diamond with inclusions that can’t be seen from top down without magnification. These are referred to as eye clean diamonds. Eye clean diamonds are much more value for money as they are less expensive and look the same as the higher grades to the naked eye.


Diamond Clarity and Diamond Shape
Fancy and step cut diamond shapes require a higher clarity grade than others. These include the Emerald and Ascher shaped diamonds as they are designed with rectangular facets that emphasize transparency and let the viewer see farther down into the diamond, making any inclusions more visible. For step cut diamond shapes it is advised to choose a VS1 clarity grade or higher so any inclusions would not be visible.

Diamond shapes that naturally hide many inclusions, such as the round, princess, oval, marquise, pear, and heart-shaped diamonds may not require as high in clarity grade. This is because they are cut with a brilliant facet pattern, which reflects light from many different angles, making it hard to see many inclusions.

 

Diamond Clarity and Diamond Size
The bigger the diamond, the easier it is to see inclusions. For bigger diamonds it is important to factor in higher clarity grades so imperfections are not easily seen within the diamond.

 

Diamond Carat Weight  
Diamond carat weight refers to the unit weight of a diamond. It measures how much a diamond weighs. One carat metric is equivalent to 200 milligrams (mg). Each carat is divided into 100 points, so a 0.75 carat diamond is equivalent to 75 points. You would hear a jeweler often referring to a 0.75 carat diamond as 75 points. If a diamond is bigger than 1 carat then they are called 1 carat its decimal weight. For example a 1.06 carat diamond would be called one point and six carats.

Carat is one of the easiest factors to choose out of the 4Cs. However, even two diamonds of the same weight will have a significant difference in value due to the difference in the diamond’s cut, color and clarity. 

It is worth noting that carat weight is not related to diamond sparkle. Beautiful sparkle that you see in diamonds is the result of good craftsmanship and a well-crafted cut. There have been many times where a high carat weight diamond with a poor cut can actually look smaller than a diamond with a smaller carat weight and an excellent cut. Even a high carat weight diamond with excellent color and high clarity can appear dull if the cut is poor. This is because the most important factor that makes a diamond sparkle is its cut. 

On a GIA certificate, the carat weight of a diamond is recorded and rounded up to two decimal points. 

History   
History of the Diamond Carat weight system? 
To understand the origins of what a diamond carat measures and how it is measured, we will investigate the origins and beginnings of the modern carat system. 
The carat weight started with the carob seed, a popular edible seed and can also be a substitute for chocolate. These carob tree seeds were even in weight. Our early gem traders used these small, uniform carob seeds as the counterweights against diamonds in their balance scales. In 1907, after the Fourth General Conference on Weights and Measures, there was an agreement whereby one carat weight in diamonds would be the equivalent to 200 milligrams of a diamond. Today, in the modern world, the carat is the same uniform milligram weight worldwide.

 

Diamond Carat Weight Magic sizes 
What do jewelers mean when they refer to diamond carat weight and “Magic Sizes”? 
In the jeweler trade, some diamond carat weights are considered “magic sizes”. These are the diamonds with carat weights just slightly below the whole and half-carat marks. To illustrate, instead of a 3.00 carat diamond, consider buying a 2.90 carat weight diamond. This will save you a significant amount of money, and the tiny slight difference will never be noticed to the naked eye. Looking down visually, there’s little difference between a 2.90 carat weight diamond and the 3.00 full carat diamond. But the price differences between the two can be significant as each one falls into a different price bracket.
You can also buy just below the half a carat or get three quarters of a carat. These magic sizes are quite rare to find so if you do find a “Magic Size” diamond, consider yourself luck and get it before someone else gets such a good deal. 

 


Diamond Carat Weight affects prices the most
Thanks to the popular market demand for bigger diamonds, the higher the carat weight of a diamond, the more expansive it is. That is because mass society has perceived that the bigger the rock, the diamond, is, the better quality it is. A bigger carat weight diamond can also emphasize one’s wealth and status. Just be aware that there are factors of the 4Cs which influence the quality and price of a diamond, including its cut, color, and clarity. 

Fancy shapes are more value for money
Fancy shaped diamonds are more value for your money as they cost less per carat compared to the equivalent carat weight of a round brilliant shaped diamond. This is because the round brilliant shaped diamond is generally more in demand and the round shaped diamond has the most sparkle compared to any other shaped diamond. 
You may have also noticed that fancy shaped diamonds can appear larger than their actual diamond carat weight size. This is especially true when a fancy shaped diamond is compared to the equivalent carat weight of a round shaped diamond. So to get the most value for your money you may consider Fancy shaped diamonds as an option to increase your carat weight of a diamond while staying within your budget. 

 

Diamond Carat Weight: Settings can help the appearance of diamond’s carat weight:


Settings can make a diamond appear bigger. This is especially the case when a fancy shaped diamond is set into a halo setting. A halo setting can add up to 0.5 carats onto the appearance of a diamond, perhaps more, depending on the halo size. 

Band size can also effect the look of a diamond’s carat and make the diamond appear bigger or smaller in carat weight depending on the band width size. For example, a thin band creates the perception and makes the center stone look larger. A trendy, popular band to achieve this look is the pave band. The pave band, which showcases small diamonds in the band also provides the added benefit of more sparkle to the diamond as the small diamonds themselves also sparkle in the light.

 


Diamond Carat Weight: Size of your finger and hand can make a diamond look bigger
The smaller and slenderer your fingers are, the bigger and larger your diamond would seem. This is all relative to size and ratio of the hand. To illustrate, a -carat diamond solitaire will look huge on a size 6 finger than compared to a size 8 finger.
